content:
Tjenga and the 
 eland man 
 
 Traditional San story 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 This story is about two friends, Tjenga
 and Ngu. They understod each other,
 played together, hunted together and
 
 shared their fod. Tjenga left his family
 and went to stay with Ngu’s family.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Early one morning Tjenga left to hunt in 
 the bush. After searching for some time, 
 
 the young hunter found the fotprint of 
 an antelope on the ground. It belonged to 
 an eland, the most beautiful of al 
 
 antelopes. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Quietly, he folowed the eland’s fotprints. Careful not to step on any dry,
 noisy gras, he walked, crawled and crept al day long until he finaly found
 the eland. It was grazing on a hil. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Quietly, Tjenga set his arow in the bow
 and puled until the string was tight and
 
 ready. He aimed at the eland’s heart.
 Tjenga released the poison arow and it
 flew through the air. The arow hit the
 
 eland’s heart. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Tjenga was afraid because he had shot 
 
 the beautiful eland. He lay down silently 
 in the bush, resting and waiting for the 
 poison arow to do its work. The sky and 
 
 the air around Tjenga shivered from the 
 miday heat while the hunter waited for 
 
 the eland to die. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 Sudenly, the eland turned into a person. Tjenga’s heart was even more
 
 afraid, for he did not mean to kil a person. What would the people say if they
 found that he had kiled a person? 
 
 
 Tjenga walked to his friend Ngu, to tel him what had hapened. 
 When he found his friend and told him the news, he said, “I am in big trouble.
 
 I hunted an eland and after I shot it, it became a person. Please, you must
 help me now so that I can bury it before the people se what I have done.”
 Ngu said, “Oh no! You are not my own family. I canot make your problem
 
 my problem!” 
 
 
 With a sore heart, the young hunter returned to his own people. Tjenga told
 them his story. Without saying much, his father said, “Come, let us go and
 have a lok.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When the family got to the hunting
 ground where Tjenga had shot the eland,
 
 they did not find a dead person there.
 The father said, “Did you lie to me?”
 “No,” said the boy, “I told you about my
 
 hunt and the eland man just as I saw it.”
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 His mother said, “You did not kil a person. This is meat, it is an animal and
 
 we must eat it because we are hungry. We ned its skin to make clothes.
 That is why you shot the eland. From now on you must understand that
 people are people and animals are animals.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Tjenga’s family made more fire. They
 danced al night and celebrated the fod
 
 that the hunter had brought home.
 Tjenga’s father said to him, “Now you
 have learnt a great leson. You canot
 
 leave your own people and adopt 
 another. When you are in serious trouble,
 
 it is your own people who wil help you
 and not your friends.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 Story notes 
 In 198 !Xun storyteler Manuel Maseka (1954–206) told this traditional
 oral story to Kapilolo Mahongo, who retold it in Afrikans to Marlene
 
 Winberg, who retold it in English. Manuel Maseka explained that it was a
 tale about a young hunter, Tjenga’s remorse at kiling the eland. Tjenga’s
 
 elders explain to the young hunter that the beautiful antelope is not a human
 being, that animals and people are diferent. As with many San stories, this
 one hints at the primeval time before humans and animals were separated
 
 from each other. It also teaches about the diference betwen family and
 friends. 
 
 
 The ilustrations in this story are from story boards by Marlene Winberg,
 interpreted digitaly by Satsiri Winberg through manipulations of the
 
 Manyeka Art Colection of paintings made by San artists /Thalu Rumao,
 /Tuoi Samcuia and Joao Wene Dikuango, who have al pased away since.
